items.title: Truth review – Julian Assange play is hard going, with flashes of brilliance
items.summary:
- The play 'Truth' is directed by Susie Dee and written by Patricia Cornelius, focusing on Julian Assange and geopolitical issues.
- It features five actors representing different facets of Assange, but the portrayal lacks nuance, emphasizing grievance instead.
- Key themes include Assange's hacking background, the WikiLeaks controversy, and comparisons with figures like Chelsea Manning and Edward Snowden.
- Cornelius presents a one-dimensional view of Assange as a leftist figure without acknowledging conflicting narratives.
- Certain scenes unrelated to Assange resonate thematically, highlighting emotional stakes.
- Although some production elements are compelling, the overall narrative is described as a slog lacking depth.

items.title: Elon Musk’s startup rolls out new Grok-3 chatbot as AI competition intensifies
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s xAI releases Grok-3, the latest AI chatbot integration with X (formerly Twitter).
- Grok-3 competes with AI firms like DeepSeek, OpenAI, and Google amidst an increasing AI arms race.
- Rolled out to Premium+ subscribers; a new subscription tier, SuperGrok, also launched for mobile app users.
- Grok-3 can generate texts and images, lacking guardrails against explicit content, leading to its misuse.
- Musk claims Grok-3 boasts over 10 times the computing power of Grok-2 and introduces a search engine called DeepSearch.
- Investors are raising billions to enhance xAI’s data capacity, and Musk’s supercomputer cluster, Colossus, is touted as the largest globally.
- A recent $97.4 billion proposal to acquire OpenAI’s assets was rejected by the company.

items.title: Elon Musk keeps bringing his kids to work – and the reasons aren’t cute at all
items.author: Arwa Mahdawi
items.summary:
- Elon Musk has been bringing his children to high-profile political events, raising public attention and generating memes.
- His son X Æ A-Xii was present at meetings with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and was seen at a press conference with Trump.
- Opinions are divided on Musk's parenting approach, with some viewing it as a cute display, while others see it as a manipulative PR strategy.
- Critics argue that Musk is using his children as props rather than engaging in genuine parenting.
- Grimes, the mother of Musk's children, has publicly expressed concern over this behavior and its implications for their privacy.

items.title: Children are starting school unable to sit up or hold a pencil – and I know the culprit
items.author: Kathryn Peckham
items.summary:
- Many children in England and Wales are starting school unable to sit up or hold a pencil, attributed to excessive screen time.
- A recent survey reports increased anxieties and inability to bond among children, leading to academic struggles.
- Lockdowns during the pandemic worsened pre-existing developmental issues due to increased reliance on screens for entertainment.
- Children require physical activity and social interaction for healthy development, which is hindered by too much screen time.
- Excessive screen time is associated with negative outcomes like reduced language skills and increased emotional reactivity.
- Vulnerable children, especially from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, are disproportionately affected by high screen time rates.

items.title: East Is South review – weighty AI drama takes aim at humanity’s biggest questions
items.summary:
- Beau Willimon's play 'East Is South' explores AI's ethics but lacks engaging momentum.
- Kaya Scodelario plays Lena, a coder facing ethical dilemmas surrounding advanced AI, Logos.
- The play struggles with pacing and emotional depth, failing to inspire genuine tension.
- Themes include humanity, love, and the potential dangers of AI but are presented without originality.
- The production is compared unfavorably to other contemporary plays about technology, like 'More Life'.

items.title: ‘No micro transactions, no bullshit’: Josef Fares on Split Fiction and the joy of co-op video games
items.summary:
- Josef Fares is known for his outspoken nature in the video game industry, advocating for creative freedom.
- His transition from film to game-making was fueled by a lifelong passion for gaming, beginning with his early experiences with an Atari.
- Fares' game, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons, was released in 2013 and has sold over 10 million copies.
- His studio, Hazelight, specializes in story-driven co-op games, starting from the idea of a shared storytelling experience.
- His latest game, Split Fiction, promises thrilling co-op gameplay reminiscent of his prior works, focusing on variation and pacing.
- Fares expresses concern over the trend of live service games and advocates for creativity in gaming without microtransactions.

items.title: Lost Records: Bloom & Rage (Tape One) review – go back to a riot grrrl summer in clever teen thriller
items.summary:
- The game is a new narrative adventure by Don’t Nod, set in 1995 and focused on teen friendships.
- Features characters Swann, Nora, Autumn, and Kat, who form a band called Bloom & Rage and discover supernatural elements.
- The story alternates between the summer of 1995 and their lives as adults in 2022.
- Players can capture memories using a camcorder mechanic that reflects on nostalgia and memory editing.
- The dialogue system mimics real-life group dynamics, showcasing the chaotic nature of teen relationships.
- The game effectively immerses players in 90s culture through surroundings and references.
- Mystery elements are teased for the second part of the game, centering on character relationships and conflicts.

items.title: Double screen: Beast Games blurs the line between YouTube and television
items.summary:
- Beast Games is a reality competition series on Amazon Prime Video, hosted by YouTuber MrBeast (Jimmy Donaldson).
- The show features 1,000 contestants battling for a $5 million prize using 1,107 cameras in a created warehouse environment.
- It has garnered 50 million viewers in 25 days, becoming Amazon Prime Video's most-watched unscripted series.
- Critics describe the show as visually poor despite its high production budget, highlighting its dystopian themes related to capitalism.
- The series merges YouTube's aesthetics with traditional television, raising questions about the evolution of TV content.

items.title: Meta plans to link US and India with world’s longest undersea cable project
items.summary:
- Meta is launching Project Waterworth, the world’s longest underwater cable project, connecting the US, India, South Africa, Brazil, and other regions.
- The cable will span 50,000km (31,000 miles), featuring a 24 fibre-pair system for enhanced capacity, aimed at supporting Meta's AI projects.
- The project is expected to improve connectivity, facilitate economic cooperation, and support India's digital economy ambitions.

items.title: How I learned to love my alarm clock
Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra review: still the superphone to beat
items.summary:
- The Galaxy S25 Ultra features advanced AI tools and technologies.
- Priced at £1,249, it offers a 6.9in QHD+ screen and Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite chip.
- New drawing tools and an improved AI assistant are included, but performance varies.
- The camera system includes a 200MP main camera and improved low-light capabilities.
- Battery life lasts about two days under normal use.
- The design is slimmer and lighter than its predecessor, weighing 218g.
- Samsung provides software updates and security patches for seven years following its release.

items.title: ‘Reading is part of my identity’: the woman taking on Goodreads owner Amazon
items.summary:
- Nadia Odunayo, a software engineer from London, created The StoryGraph in response to dissatisfaction with Goodreads after it was acquired by Amazon in 2013.
- The StoryGraph now has 3.8 million active users with features like AI-driven recommendations and reader tracking tools.
- There are ongoing concerns about Goodreads, such as user experiences of hostility and issues with fake reviews, with a prominent incident involving author Cait Corrain in 2023.
- Odunayo aims to keep The StoryGraph independent and is committed to enhancing the user experience.

items.title: Parents are desperate to protect kids on social media. Why did the US let a safety bill die?
items.summary:
- The Kids Online Safety Act (Kosa) failed to pass after being introduced in 2022, despite strong backing in the Senate.  
- Advocates for Kosa emphasized the need for tech companies to protect child users from online harm.  
- The bill included a "duty of care" clause, requiring platforms to act in minors' best interests, raising concerns about potential censorship.  
- Critics stressed that vague definitions of harmful content could lead to over-filtering of sensitive topics.  
- Despite failure, advocates plan to reintroduce Kosa due to persistent concerns for kids' online safety.

items.title: Protesters target Tesla showrooms in US over Elon Musk’s government cost-cutting
items.summary:
- Protesters gathered outside Tesla dealerships across the US in response to Elon Musk's government spending cuts.
- Demonstrations occurred in cities including New York, Seattle, and Kansas City, with up to 100 people in attendance at some locations.
- Many protesters criticized Musk's association with Trump's administration, carrying placards with strong anti-Trump imagery.
- Musk is part of a government division aimed at efficiency, but actions have drawn legal criticisms.
- Some Tesla investors are concerned about potential sales impacts in liberal markets due to Musk's political affiliations.
- American musician Sheryl Crow decided to sell her Tesla and supported NPR, criticizing Musk's government position.
- Tesla experienced its first annual sales decline in 2024; debate continues on whether political views contributed to this.
- Significant declines in Tesla sales were noted, particularly in Germany following Musk's support for far-right politics.

items.title: Amazon accused of targeting Coventry union members after failed recognition vote
items.summary:
- Amazon is accused of targeting 60 trade union members with disciplinary actions after a failed recognition vote at its Coventry warehouse.
- The GMB union claims the targeted workers were involved in actions leading to a recognition ballot that narrowly lost last summer.
- Disciplinary actions have reportedly increased since the vote, with allegations of rule changes in productivity metrics affecting workers negatively.
- A survey revealed 81% of GMB members working at Amazon are dissatisfied with their jobs.
- Amazon denies these claims, stating there have been no changes to break times and asserting that it does not monitor union membership.

items.title: Elon Musk’s mass government cuts could make private companies millions
items.summary:
- Elon Musk plans to defund public programs and lay off federal workers, framing this as waste removal.
- His initiative, called "department of government efficiency" (Doge), targets major agencies like USAID and the Department of Education.
- Private companies, including Musk’s own ventures, may benefit significantly from these cuts as they take over government functions.
- Notable support comes from Silicon Valley firms, including Palantir, praising the disruption as advantageous.
- Concerns have been raised about the ethical implications of Musk's influence on federal contracts and potential conflicts of interest, reinforced by Trump's executive orders supporting these changes.

items.title: If the AI Roundheads go to war with tech royalty, don’t bet against them
items.summary:
- Tech giants like Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, and Meta plan to spend over $320 billion on AI in 2025, up from $246 billion in 2024.
- The industry is driven by the fear of missing out (FOMO) and the prospect of first-mover advantages in achieving artificial general intelligence (AGI).
- A divide is emerging between 'AI Cavaliers' aiming for AGI and 'AI Roundheads' focused on practical AI applications, with DeepMind's Demis Hassabis exemplifying the latter's success.

items.title: Saying ‘women’ is not allowed, but ‘men’ and ‘white’ are OK? I’m (not) shocked
items.summary:
- Donald Trump's executive orders are censoring terms like 'women' from official language and documents.
- Federal agencies, including NASA and CDC, have removed references to women and gender in compliance with these orders.
- Researchers are self-censoring to avoid issues with grant applications if they use terms considered problematic, which may impact important public health research.
- The National Science Foundation has created a list of forbidden words, including 'women', which staff must navigate carefully in research proposals.
- This trend indicates a shift towards policing language that is seen as ambiguous or politically sensitive, leading to concerns about academic freedom and research integrity.

items.title: UK-based lawyers for Hong Kong activist Jimmy Lai targeted by Chinese state
‘Everyone knows the Centrelink song’: how we learned to love – and remix – hold music
items.summary:
- Triple J played the Centrelink hold music for eight hours straight; it's now part of cultural zeitgeist.
- TikTok influencer Lyanna Kea's dance to the tune gained significant popularity online.
- The song was created by Tim Carleton in 1989 and recorded by Darrick Deel, becoming well-known through Cisco.
- In 2018, Centrelink switched its hold music to this synth melody.
- The song has been incorporated into various art forms and performances during lockdowns.
- A good hold song requires a decent beat and consistent volume without provoking strong emotions.
- Professor Lauren Rosewarne cautions that attempts to capitalize on the meme could kill its humorous appeal.

items.title: OpenAI rejects $97.4bn Musk bid and says company is not for sale
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- OpenAI rejected a $97.4bn bid from Elon Musk's consortium, stating it is not for sale.
- Musk, a co-founder of OpenAI, aims to prevent the company from becoming for-profit.
- OpenAI's board reinforced its commitment to its nonprofit mission via a statement on X.
- Sam Altman, OpenAI's CEO, acknowledged the rejection to Axios and responded to Musk's remarks.
- Musk's consortium would drop its offer if OpenAI cancels plans to transition to a for-profit entity.
- The OpenAI board condemned Musk's bid as not a legitimate offer after recent court filings.

items.title: Every picture tells a story: the joy of analogue photography | Letters
items.author: Julius Smit, David R Freke, Roger Foster, David Baugh
items.summary:
- Sundus Abdi advocates for analogue photography over digital for capturing personal moments.
- The resurgence of film-processing labs in Britain indicates a renewed interest in film photography.
- The tactile experience of hard-copy prints is cited as a vital aspect of preserving memories compared to digital images.
- Various contributors share their positive experiences with analogue photography, highlighting the anticipation of developed pictures.
- Concerns are raised about the soullessness of digital image storage compared to traditional photo albums.

items.title: Musk-linked group offered $5m for proof of voter fraud – and came up with nothing
items.summary:
- The Fair Election Fund aimed to reward whistleblowers with a $5m fund to expose election fraud, but failed to present evidence.
- The group’s ads and campaigns did not yield any credible information regarding voter fraud, reaffirming that it is extremely rare.
- Despite the lack of evidence, Republicans continue to push restrictive voting laws based on unsubstantiated claims of fraud.

items.title: Arm looks to launch its own chip after landing Meta contract
items.summary:
- Arm plans to launch its own chip in 2025, with Meta as a key customer.
- This marks a shift from licensing chip designs to producing its own chips, competing with major clients.
- CEO Rene Haas to unveil the first chip this summer.
- Over 300 billion Arm-based chips have been shipped since 1990.
- The launch is part of a larger strategy by SoftBank to enhance revenue from its intellectual property.

items.title: ‘Less Star Wars – more Blade Runner’: the making of Mass Effect 2’s Bafta-nominated soundtrack
items.summary:
- Mass Effect is hailed as one of the best sci-fi franchises, blending various themes and genres.
- Composer Jack Wall was chosen through a blind audition to create the soundtrack for Mass Effect, aiming for an '80s sci-fi music sound.
- The music of Mass Effect 2, particularly the track 'Suicide Mission', became integral to the game, reflecting a darker tone compared to the first game.
- Wall implemented all the music for Mass Effect 2 himself, significantly improving transitions and overall audio experience.
- The game's ending sequence remains one of the best in gaming, contributing to the emotional weight of the player's choices.

items.title: TikTok returns to Apple App Store and Google Play in US
items.summary:
- TikTok returned to US app stores as Trump delayed a ban on the app.
- The app briefly went dark before a law took effect on January 19 requiring its Chinese owner ByteDance to either sell it or face a ban.
- Trump's executive order delayed the enforcement of the ban by 75 days.
- TikTok was temporarily operational after Trump's assurances that Google and Apple would not be fined for distributing it.
- The app had over 52 million downloads in 2024, with 52% from Apple and 48% from Google.
- The law mandating the sale of TikTok’s US assets was signed by Biden in April last year.
- Trump indicated that his 75-day deadline for TikTok could be extended.

items.title: UK Private Hire Drivers Strike for Fair Pay and Rights on Valentine’s Day
items.summary:
- Private hire drivers in the UK are staging a log-off action on Valentine’s Day to demand better pay and working conditions.
- Simon Waite, a driver, notes that he now works about 70 hours a week to earn £1,000, up from 50 hours previously.
- The Independent Workers’ Union of Great Britain (IWGB) supports the action, citing worsened conditions post-2021 court ruling on drivers’ rights.
- Uber denies claims of unfair pay and states most drivers earn more than the national living wage.
- Many drivers report struggling to meet their living expenses and feel exploited by low fare rates.

items.title: Global disunity, energy concerns and the shadow of Musk: key takeaways from the Paris AI summit
items.summary:
- The Paris AI summit showcased global tensions regarding AI development among political and business leaders.
- US Vice President JD Vance emphasized a unilateral approach to AI, opposing global regulations and caution against collaborating with authoritarian regimes.
- Both the US and UK declined to sign a diplomatic declaration on AI governance, signaling a lack of consensus among major nations.
- Discussions included the environmental impact of AI and its potential to exacerbate global inequalities.
- The speed of AI progress was highlighted, with predictions that advanced AI systems could emerge within the next few years.
- China proposed collaboration for security and shared advancements in AI, despite its absence from the summit.
- Elon Musk's influence was felt at the summit due to a significant bid for control over OpenAI, raising concerns about the organization’s future.

items.title: Elon Musk says he’ll drop his $97bn bid for OpenAI if it remains a non-profit
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Elon Musk will abandon his $97.4bn offer to buy OpenAI if it remains a non-profit.
- Musk's lawyers stated that if OpenAI's Board halts conversion to for-profit, he will withdraw the bid.
- OpenAI, originally founded by Musk, plans to change its corporate structure amid rapid growth.
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman rejected the bid and stated the company is not for sale.
- Musk criticized Altman's management during a video call at the World Government Summit.

items.title: Scarlett Johansson warns of dangers of AI after Kanye West deepfake goes viral
items.summary:
- Scarlett Johansson highlights the imminent dangers of AI following a viral deepfake video featuring her and other Jewish celebrities against antisemitism.
- The deepfake video includes AI-generated likenesses of over a dozen stars, including David Schwimmer, Jerry Seinfeld, and Mila Kunis, and ends with a message against antisemitism.
- Johansson calls for action against the misuse of AI, emphasizing it poses a greater threat than individual accountability for hate speech.
- Kanye West (now Ye) has faced backlash for antisemitic remarks, including references to Nazis and selling controversial merchandise, which led to account deactivation and ad condemnation.
- Johansson has previously opposed AI usage without consent and has called for legislative measures against AI abuses to protect citizens.

items.title: Avowed review – Annihilation meets Oblivion in a vast, intricate fantasy
items.summary:
- Avowed is an expansive fantasy RPG by Obsidian set in the universe of the Pillars of Eternity games.
- The game's visual style blends elements from Annihilation and Oblivion, featuring rich environments and an engaging storyline.
- Players assume the role of an envoy investigating a disturbing plague that drives people mad.
- The game offers deep character interactions and a strong sense of player agency, steering away from simplistic good/evil choices.
- Initial gameplay experience is rich and engaging, with vast exploration opportunities but suffers from repetitiveness and combat issues over time.
- Avowed is set to be released on 18 February, with a price of £59.99.

items.title: The best iPhones in 2025: which Apple smartphone is right for you, according to our expert
items.summary:
- The iPhone 16 is considered the best for most users, priced from £799.
- The iPhone SE (2022) is recognized as the best value option, starting at £429.
- The iPhone 16 Pro is the top choice for photography enthusiasts, starting from £999.
- The iPhone 16 Pro Max offers the largest screen experience at £1,199.
- The base model iPhone 16 features AI tools, a 48MP camera, and offers a two-day battery life.
- iPhone 16 Plus provides a larger screen and better battery life for around £899.
- The iPhone SE retains the classic design but includes modern internals like the A15 processor and 5G support.

items.title: Rogue states could use AI to do ‘real harm’, warns ex-Google CEO
items.author: Eric Schmidt
items.summary:
- Eric Schmidt, former Google CEO, warns that AI could be misused by rogue states like North Korea, Iran, and Russia.
- He highlights the potential for developing harmful weapons, including biological attacks.
- Schmidt supports US export controls on AI technology to prevent misuse by adversaries.
- He advocates for government oversight of AI development while cautioning against over-regulation.
- Schmidt participated in the AI Action summit in Paris, where the UK and US declined to sign an inclusive AI agreement.
- He expresses concerns about the impact of smartphones on children and supports a ban on social media for those under 16.

items.title: US Department of State plans to spend $400m on Tesla armoured vehicles
items.summary:
- The US Department of State plans to spend $400m on Tesla armoured vehicles, likely Cybertrucks.
- This procurement raises concerns over conflicts of interest as Elon Musk benefits from government contracts.
- Contract award is expected by the end of September, with the forecast document modified to remove Tesla's name from one reference.

items.title: I made the worst role-playing game of all time – and loved every minute of it
items.summary:
- The author created a role-playing game called Artisan Cheese Quest using RPG Maker in about two hours with their son.
- RPG Maker has been available since 1992 and allows users to create games without prior development experience.
- Many acclaimed indie games have been made with RPG Maker, but the author humorously notes Artisan Cheese Quest won't join their ranks.
- The game features a festival setting, involves players finding a cheese festival pass, and employs simple visual programming for events and dialogue.
- Creating the game was fun for the author and their son, with silly sound effects enhancing the experience.
- Despite the initial ease, the system becomes complex with advanced game mechanics and creating fighting encounters.

items.title: Rape under wraps: how Tinder, Hinge and their corporate owner chose profits over safety
items.summary:
- The Dating Apps Reporting Project conducted an 18-month investigation into Match Group's safety practices regarding dating apps like Tinder and Hinge.
- Multiple women reported that Stephen Matthews, a user, had sexually assaulted them; despite reports, he remained active on the platforms.
- Matthews was eventually sentenced to 158 years to life in prison for drugging and assaulting eight women.
- Match Group's official safety policy prohibits users reported for assault but failed to act on repeated reports against Matthews.
- The company has internal records indicating knowledge of abusive users but has delayed public transparency reports on sexual assault incidents.
- Concerns about prioritizing corporate growth over user safety have been raised, leading to calls for more robust safety measures.

items.title: X to pay Donald Trump $10m to settle lawsuit over Capitol attack – report
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's platform X will pay Donald Trump $10m to settle a lawsuit filed after Trump was banned post-January 6 Capitol attack.
- The lawsuit was initiated under former CEO Jack Dorsey, but Trump’s legal team considered abandoning it after Musk reinstated Trump's account.
- This settlement follows a previous $25m payment by Meta to Trump over a similar issue, and Trump's attorneys may pursue further settlements with Google as well.

items.title: Google defends scrapping AI pledges and DEI goals in all-staff meeting
Top of the flops: just what does the games industry deem ‘success’ any more?
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Square Enix labeled the 2013 Tomb Raider reboot, which sold 3.4 million copies in the first month, a disappointment due to unmet sales expectations.
- EA's CEO reported that Dragon Age: The Veilguard, launched in October 2024, reached 1.5 million players but did not resonate widely, leading to claims of it being a failure.
- Despite the perception of failure, 1.5 million players is a respectable number compared to sales of other RPGs in similar release periods.
- The unrealistic expectations for new games lead to significant consequences for developers like BioWare, which has seen drastic staffing reductions following the release of Dragon Age.

items.title: How Harrison Ford brought a strike over use of AI in video games to the world’s attention
items.summary:
- Harrison Ford praised voice actor Troy Baker for his performance in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, emphasizing the value of human talent over AI.
- Video game performers in SAG-AFTRA have been on strike since July due to concerns regarding the use of generative AI in the industry.
- The union demands compensation and transparency when AI-generated performances are produced based on their work.
- Major publishers like Activision Blizzard, Disney, and Electronic Arts are involved, affecting recent game titles.
- Over 160 video game productions have voluntarily agreed to AI protections, but major publishers are hesitant to comply fully.
- SAG-AFTRA alleges companies seek loopholes to exploit actors’ previous performances without consent or compensation, impacting all performers.

items.title: The Hidden Costs of Facebook's Content Moderation: A Personal Account
items.author: Sonia Kgomo
items.summary:
- Sonia Kgomo shares her experiences as a content moderator for Facebook through the subcontractor Sama, highlighting the psychological toll of viewing graphic content.
- Many moderators face impossible quotas and lack mental health support, leading to widespread trauma and anxiety.
- A class action lawsuit is underway in Kenya against Sama and Facebook, revealing systemic issues in outsourcing digital labor.
- There is a growing movement, African Tech Workers Rising, advocating for better wages and working conditions for tech workers.
- Calls for professional standards and protections for content moderators include the establishment of unions and improved mental health resources.

items.title: Elon Musk owning OpenAI would be a terrible idea. That doesn’t mean it won’t happen
items.author: Chris Stokel-Walker
items.summary:
- Elon Musk and Sam Altman have a contentious relationship, rooted in disagreements over OpenAI's direction.
- Musk has made a near $100bn bid for OpenAI’s non-profit arm, citing a desire to return to its original safety-focused mission.
- Altman rejected the bid, humorously suggesting Musk could buy Twitter instead for $9.74bn.
- Speculations arise whether Musk’s bid is a serious strategic move or a mischievous ploy.
- The article discusses the potential implications of Trump's interest in OpenAI amidst Musk's efforts to reshape it.

items.title: Beats Powerbeats Pro 2 review: Apple’s best workout buds are back with a bang
items.summary:
- Apple has released the Powerbeats Pro 2, an upgrade from the original version after five years.
- The new earbuds include noise cancelling and heart rate monitoring features, retailing at £250 ($250).
- They offer approximately 8 hours of playback with noise cancelling (10 hours without), and come with a charging case providing 3.5 additional charges.
- Connectivity utilizes the H2 chip, allowing compatibility with Apple devices and advanced features on Android including one-touch pairing.
- The earbuds boast excellent sound quality and effective noise cancelling, alongside a well-performing transparency mode.
- Heart rate sensors can monitor pulse and sync with compatible workout apps on both iOS and Android.
- Features solid construction with IPX4 water resistance, but battery life is not user-replaceable, raising sustainability concerns.
- They are priced competitively compared to other premium workout earbuds.

items.title: World leaders and tech bosses focus on innovation Paris AI summit – video highlights
items.summary:
- Collaboration and opportunity were emphasized in the discussions at the summit.
- JD Vance encouraged European leaders to adopt an optimistic view of AI technology.
- The US and UK declined to sign a declaration on inclusive and sustainable AI, facing criticism from campaign groups regarding the UK's reputation in this area.

items.title: Google Calendar removes Black History Month, Pride and other cultural events
items.summary:
- Google has removed references to Black History Month, Women’s History Month, and LGBTQ+ holidays from its online calendars for 2025.
- The change was attributed to sustainability issues in maintaining a broad set of cultural moments globally.
- Users are now required to manually add these events to their calendars, drawing disappointment from many on social media.
- Despite these changes, Google will continue to celebrate cultural events through its products, like YouTube Music's playlists.

items.title: How Musk and Trump are flooding the zone
items.summary:
- Elon Musk and Donald Trump employ a tactic known as 'flooding the zone' to overwhelm opposition and media.
- Trump has issued a record number of executive orders affecting immigration and trade, while Musk aims to streamline government efficiency by targeting various federal agencies.
- ICE has manipulated Google search results by updating old press releases to appear recent, obscuring the reality of its operations.
- Spotify attempts to humanize its AI-driven recommendation algorithms amidst criticism from artists like Björk, while still focusing heavily on AI technology.

items.title: US and UK not among signatories of Paris AI summit declaration
items.summary:
- The US and UK have not signed the Paris AI summit’s declaration on artificial intelligence.
- The declaration emphasizes AI being open, inclusive, transparent, ethical, safe, secure, and trustworthy.
- The Élysée Palace mentioned that more countries might sign the declaration after the event.

items.title: UK copyright law consultation ‘fixed’ in favour of [AI companies](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=AI%20companies), peer says
items.author: Beeban Kidron
items.summary:
- Consultation on UK copyright law changes criticized for favoring AI companies.
- Beeban Kidron claims it will shift wealth from creative industries to [creative industries](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=creative%20industries) sector.
- Government favors relaxing copyright restrictions for AI developers.
- Proposed options include unchanged situation, licensing requirements, or no opt-out for creators.
- Kidron's amendments aim to reinforce rights for copyright owners and transparency for AI use.
- Government asserts it's important to remain open-minded about the consultation process.

items.title: How Meta abandoned Silicon Valley’s most ambitious diversity goals
items.summary:
- In 2019, [Facebook](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=facebook) aimed for 50% diverse workforce by 2024.
- Meta announced end to diversity goals just after 2024.
- DEI programs, once a priority, have been abandoned.
- CEO [Mark Zuckerberg](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=markzuckerberg) shifted goals for ‘free expression’ over DEI.
- Former Facebook diversity officer Maxine Williams reassigned.
- Recent policy changes allow derogatory terms against marginalized groups.

items.title: Campaigner for migrants in Libya says his phone was targeted in spyware attack
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- David Yambio, a human rights activist, revealed his phone was targeted by spyware, as informed by Apple.
- He is a critic of Italy's migrant pact with Libya and involved with evidence collection for the ICC.
- Yambio received a notification on November 13 about a mercenary spyware attack potentially targeting him personally.
- An investigation is ongoing by Citizen Lab regarding the spyware targeting activists and journalists in Italy.
- Yambio's case raises concerns about political implications and the safety of ICC witnesses.
